For $0 \le x \le 40$ and $0 \le y \le 50,$ find the minimum value of
\[\sqrt{x^2 + 400} + \sqrt{y^2 + 900} + \sqrt{x^2 + y^2 - 80x - 100y + 4100}.\]

ost_step.1: Let us define $f(a)=\sqrt{a^2 + 400}$, so our expression becomes \[\sqrt{x^2 + 400}+ \sqrt{y^2 + 900}+ f(x)+ g(y)+\ h(x, y)\] where \[g(y) =\sqrt{y^2 + 900}, \]and $$h(x, y) =\sqrt{x^2 + y^2 - 80x - 100y + 4100}$$is called function \(C\) defined over domain \(\left\{ {\left( {x,y} \right)|0 \leqslant x \leqslant 40,\; 0 \leqslant y \leqslant 50} \right\}\text{.}\) It seems counterintuitive—the problem statement asks what happens when both variables increase toward infinity! However, it turns out such behavior doesn’t occur since each term increases monotonically as one variable goes up within the limits.\begin{aligned}& \lim_{{x \to +\infty }} {{f(x)} \over x}=0 \\& \quad \lim_{{y \to +\infty }}{g(
ost_step.2: Consider how much closer together any pair of opposite corners would need to get before another vertex could slip inside them. Thus let us minimize \[\max \{r(p),\;\rho(q),\;d(u,v)\}\]where $$\begin{aligned} r(p)&:=||\mathbf i||=1\\ \rho(q)&:=\frac{|(\overline p-\overline q)(p+q)}{4|p|^2}\\ d(u, v):&= ||u-v||_{\infty}=\max |ux-vy|, \; u=(x',y'),\; v=(x,y)\\ & &x'\in[0,\,N],\; y'\in[0,\,M]\end{aligned}$$for some fixed large integers $N$ and $M.$ As discussed earlier [see below], letting $|N|$ or $|M|$ grow without bound won’t help because no additional corner gets added into play regardless of the size chosen. That leaves maximizing the second ratio above independently.*Proof*:- Suppose firstly WLOG $[x']<[x]$ implies equality holds throughout Equation *above*, specifically whenever $\{b\}$ appears anywhere other than immediately following absolute bars.$$|\overline

0.user_question:
For $0 \le x \le 40$ and $0 \le y \le 50,$ find the minimum value of
\[\sqrt{x^2 + 400} + \sqrt{y^2 + 900} + \sqrt{x^2 + y^2 - 80x - 100y + 4100}.\]

direct_answer.text: We notice that \[\begin{aligned} & \sqrt{x^2 + 400}+\sqrt{y^2+900}+ \sqrt{(x-40)^2 + (y-50)^2 } \\ &= (\sqrt{x^2+400}-\sqrt{x^2+1600})+\text{(something)}\\ &= (\sqrt{400}-0)+\text{(something)}. \end{aligned}\]Now it suffices to minimize something without restriction, so let $x=40$ and $y=50.$ It follows that \[\begin{aligned} &\phantom{==}=(\sqrt{400}-0)+(\sqrt{2500}-0)\\ &=10+50\\ &=\boxed{60}. \end{aligned}\]The answer is: 60
